topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Cold open on prioritizing life through mortality awareness, followed by Lenny introducing J.M.’s career (Uber, DoorDash, Waymo) and setting expectations for a wide-ranging leadership conversation.

topics.title: Defining conscious leadership and influence
topics.summary: J.M. defines leadership as influence (everyone is a leader) and consciousness as awareness of one’s inner world, inherited beliefs, and biases—then taking responsibility for the impact you have.

topics.title: Soft skills, power dynamics, and creating space
topics.summary: They discuss how influence changes with seniority: J.M. shifted from being the loudest voice to intentionally holding back, inviting others to speak first, and managing power imbalances in meetings.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Pendo (product experience platform) and the Enterprise Ready Conference (enterprise SaaS product/engineering event).

topics.title: Uber culture across eras and inner work
topics.summary: J.M. contrasts Uber 1.0/2.0/3.0: early mission-driven intensity and fear-based culture, his stress building Uber Pool, and how that pushed him into meditation/coaching; he also outlines Uber’s current multi-modal future.

topics.title: Naming UberX and Uber Pool
topics.summary: A quick tangent on how UberX’s name stuck as an internal codename, and J.M. shares he helped name Uber Pool (later renamed Share).

topics.title: Allowing emotions to break stress loops
topics.summary: J.M. explains why resisting anxiety in high-stakes meetings backfires: thoughts and emotions form a reinforcing loop, and the first step is allowing them to arise and pass rather than fighting them.

topics.title: Self-worth beyond approval, control, and security
topics.summary: He describes moving from needing external approval (e.g., Dara’s) to cultivating internal self-worth, reframing feedback as a gift, and reducing fear by recognizing most moments aren’t truly “one shot.”

topics.title: Optics versus impact and purpose-driven work
topics.summary: J.M. argues that focusing less on ego/optics and more on building an awesome product can paradoxically improve outcomes and recognition; they discuss how mission alignment enables this mindset.

topics.title: Building strategy and vision through immersion
topics.summary: J.M. shares how to improve strategy/vision: choose a domain you deeply care about, immerse for years, use first-principles thinking, and vividly imagine the future (e.g., autonomy, sharing, city redesign).

topics.title: Making space for deep thinking and co-creation
topics.summary: They discuss practical ways to generate vision: carve out quiet time (runs, hikes, no media), then bring an outline to teams for long-form whiteboard sessions and Pixar-style “brain trust” riffing.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor message for Vanta (automating security compliance and trust management).

topics.title: Uber marketplace future: multi-supply and multi-demand
topics.summary: J.M. describes a key strategic realization: Uber’s marketplace is becoming far more complex with taxis, fleets, and autonomous partners on supply, and many ride products on demand—requiring new pricing, ranking, and allocation systems.

topics.title: Focus, productivity, and the three-things rule
topics.summary: They reinforce going deep at both macro and micro levels: limit daily priorities to 1–3 high-leverage items, avoid over-structured systems, and externalize to-dos to keep an “empty mind” for creativity.

topics.title: Balancing vision and execution in practice
topics.summary: J.M. explains the polarity between over-theorizing (e.g., complex pricing designs at Uber) and over-executing (“ready, fire, aim” at DoorDash), emphasizing dynamic balance depending on whether direction is clear or needs rethinking.
